title: universal credit wait campaign lords
story: And in a huge boost for The Suns Make Universal Credit Work campaign, the Lords Economic Affairs Committee backed all of our main asks of the Government for how to repair the troubled benefits programme.Around .million people were on Universal Credit as of the start of April as thousands lost their jobs as a result of the coronavirus pandemic.An extra .million people claimed for the new benefits system since March - and .million claimed advance payments.In a fresh report out today the peers argue that the five-week wait, which The Sun has been campaigning to get slashed down, is the main cause of insecurity.They said it entrenches debt and increases extreme poverty and must be addressed now.People who have had a £ boost to help during the coronavirus crisis should get to keep the cash going forward, they added.The DWP said no one has to wait five weeks for cash as urgent payments are availablepeople need them.Lord Forsyth of Drumlean, Chair of the Economic Affairs Committee, told The Sun: The Suns campaign has revealed many of these problems with Universal Credit and has been calling for change.Our report reinforces the need for the Government to act on these recommendations - and do so now.There is a great wall of unemployment sadly coming our way and there will be many more people dependent on Universal Credit. It needs fixing.One million people are already receiving it and by the time the system is fully rolled out in , nearly  million will be on it.But there are big problems with the flagship new system - it takes  weeks to get the first payment and it could leave some families worse off by thousands of pounds a year.And while working families can claim back up to  per cent of their childcare costs, they must find the money to pay for childcare upfront - we’ve heard of families waiting up to  months for the money.Working parents across the country told us they’ve been unable to take on more hours - or have even turned down better paid jobs or more hours because of the amount they get their benefits cut.It’s time to Make Universal Credit work. We want the Government to:Together, these changes will help Make Universal Credit Work.Join our Universal Credit Facebook group or email UniversalCredit@the-sun to share your story. And he added: “Most people, including our Committee, broadly agree with the original aims and objectives of Universal Credit. However, in its current form it fails to provide a dependable safety net. It has led to an unprecedented number of people relying on foodbanks and not being able to pay their rent.He said some features of the system were harming women, disabled people and the vulnerable.And he added: “Universal Credit needs more money to catch up after  years of cuts to the social security budget and substantial reform to its design.“The five-week wait for a first payment must be replaced by a non-repayable two-week grant to all claimants.The Lords report also recommends that the punitive taper rate should be reduced - another aim of The Suns campaign - to encourage more people into work.And it says all claimants should have a higher work allowance to allow them to keep more of their hard-earned cash too.The Lords also conclude that including childcare support in Universal Credit was a mistake and paying in arrears is a huge barrier to work - as we have repeatedly highlighted.In some cases it has been a disincentive to work, the report says.The Government should remove childcare support from Universal Credit and be made into a new standalone benefit paid, it added.Jonathan Reynolds MP, Labours Shadow Secretary of State for Work and Pensions, said of the report: “Sadly, this report confirms what many have known for a long time – Universal Credit is simply not working. There is clear consensus that the system is not delivering on its objectives and is instead pushing people further into poverty and debt.Ministers should listen to their Conservative colleagues’ calls for a reformed social security system.The DWP said in response to the report it would consider their recommendations in detail.Minister for Welfare Delivery Will Quince said of the report: “The case for Universal Credit has never been stronger. The system defied its critics in unprecedented and unforeseeable circumstances, processing more than .m new claims at pace since mid-March and paying more than a million advances worth hundreds of millions of pounds to those in urgent need within days.“We remain committed to supporting the most vulnerable in society, which is why we currently spend over £ billion a year on the benefits system. We’ve also increased the Universal Credit standard allowance by up to £, a year, as part of a package of welfare measures worth over £. billion.“We welcome the acknowledgement by the Committee that Universal Credit is here to stay and we will consider their recommendations in detail.”IF youre experiencing trouble applying for your Universal Credit, or the payments just dont cover costs, here are your options:Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: thousands could have wrong test coronavirus
story: In test kits sent out to millions of Brits to seethey have the virus, they were able to take nasal samples from lower down, rather than painful and uncomfortable deep swabs.These can be done at home without the supervision of a medical procedure, and scientists said they would be just as accurate.But a new study from officials at the University of Utah studied the accuracy of the self-collected nasal swap.Scientists found only  of  out of  people who had Covid- were picked up by nasal swabs, compared to the deeper ones.The deeper swabs only picked up a maximum of .However, the study has not yet been published in a medical journal or peer-reviewed. It was conducted across hospitals in Utah.It means there is a risk of people being given  negative results, and not isolating as they should.Up to  per cent of people get the virus without showing any symptoms - and people still can pass it on.Experts said that the swabs have less contact with the tissues and are less likely to pick up the bug.Professor Paul Hunter, an infectious disease expert at the University of East Anglia, said the study findings certainly suggest these DIY tests are not as good and miss a proportion.He claimed around  per cent of coronavirus tests could have been missed.But Professor Hunter told MailOnline the study does not prove the tests are useless and called for larger trials of the swabs currently being used in the UK. He said: This study is fairly small and it needs to be repeated using a larger number of tests, preferably in the UK, before we draw reliable conclusions.No singular test produced  results, proving that no test is able to always detect the coronavirus. But researchers said the numbers were not statistically signicant as the numbers are so small.The researchers wrote: Relying on anterior nasal swabs alone could have missed infection in  to  patients compared with nasopharyngeal swabs or saliva, respectively. Missed Covid- cases have major clinical implications affecting isolation decisions for symptomatic  patients and are a lost opportunity for contact tracing.  The Department of Health and Social Care refuted the findings, saying the evidence shows self-tests are just as effective.A spokesperson said: International peer reviewed evidence, and real-world assessments from the Department’s testing programme, has shown that swab tests taken by non-clinically trained iniduals are just as effective as those taken by clinicians. Instructions on how to perform these types of tests are included wherever iniduals are asked to undertake self-swabbing.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: what no deal brexit mean for uk
story: Negotiations continue, but the EU and UK still disagree over future arrangements for areas such as fisheries, state aid and financial services.A No Deal departure from the European Union means leaving without formal arrangements for the future relationship.Britains trade, customs and immigration rules were tied up with the single market and a host of EU regulatory bodies.Mr Johnson had insisted Britain would leave the EU on October  do or die - and was prepared to leave with no deal.The PM said he would rather be dead in a ditch than ask the EU for another Brexit extension.But a proposed law blocking a No Deal Brexit was backed by MPs on September ,  and was passed in the Lords on September .The Benn Act required the Government to either reach a deal - or gain Parliaments approval for a No Deal Brexit by October .The UK ended up leaving the EU on January  with a transition period until December  .While we did leave with a deal - in which this transition period was agreed - there is still the possibility of ending up in a no deal scenario still.If there is no arrangement for our future relationship by the end of this period then Britain will have left the EU with no deal and will trade on World Trade Organisation rules.In August  John Bercow fought with the government to stop it forcing through its Brexit deal by closing parliament.At the same time several Remainer MPs and anti-Brexit lawyers were trying to stop a No-Deal.Days before the Prime Ministers July deadline - the last opportunity to extend the transition period - ministers said Britain is close to abandoning a trade deal.Boris Johnsons most senior aide Dominic Cummings has been pressuring the UKs negotiators to stick to red lines as tightly as possible in order to get the best possible deal for Britain, according to EU insiders.Deputy negotiator Oliver Lewis, who is a close ally of Mr Cummings, was identied as a key blockage in the talks.It came after the EUs chief negotiator Michel Barnier said he would ease his red lines provided Boris Johnsons government showed some compromise.But British and EU negotiators have agreed  percent of a deal and were gunning for a breakthrough on a post-Brexit security pact.To avoid a No Deal, the UK government must agree its future relationship with the EU - the aims of which were established in the -page political declaration.A free-trade agreement is the priority and talks, which started in March, are set to intensy to achieve this.During this transition period the UK is still a member of the single market and the customs union.Butwe leave without a deal we will not be a member of either and have nothing firmed up to replace it, which means Britain will be forced to trade according to the World Trade Organisation - the global body overseeing international trade.This could lead to greater tarfs on imports and exports - resulting in a price hike.Other aspects are also subject to a deal being reached, includingThe Government has launched a new Check, Change, Go slogan to encourage the public to prepare for the end of the transition period in January .A questionnaire on the gov.uk website allows you to answer a few questions in order to get personalised advice on what you should do to prepare for the looming deadline.Businesses are encouraged to start preparing for a new approach to trade with our partners in the European Union.It added: For iniduals this may include registering your residency rights.

title: bakery worker sacked 44 years pay cash
story: Megan Metcalfe, , was given her marching orders by Birds Bakery in Radclfe-on-Trent, Notts, after it stopped accepting cash for hygiene reasons.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesShe accepted around £ in cash from customers and then used her debit card to pay for the transactions.Ms Metcalfe said: “I realise what I was doing was against company policy. But they had picked up the items and already gotten to the till ready to buy them.”“There’s no way I could let an elderly man or woman walk away telling them they could not buy it because they didn’t have a card. They had also already handled the stock so that would have to be binned or cleaned.”Ms Metcalfe was suspended on June  and then sacked following a disciplinary hearing, with the firm saying it was “with regret” they had to let her go.She added: “I was just trying to do the right thing. I am really upset by it, of course.“I worked at Birds for  years and  of them as a manager. I was told I was endangering staff members’ lives by doing what I did.“At no point did money transfer hands. It was straight into my purse and then I put the payment through on card and showed them the receipt.“I should not have done it but I don’t like to let people down and a lot of these customers depend on us, coming to us every day.”More than a thousand people angered by the sacking have signed an online petition calling for her to be re-employed or compensated.The petition says: Megan Metcalfe was sacked for being kind to her elderly customers in Birds Bakery, after  years of service.“We the people of Nottingham think that decision is absolutely disgusting, no matter the companys Covid- rules on payment processing, the decision to treat a loyal employee this way for a letimes service is beyond belief.It should be handled more appropriately via a simple disciplinary meeting or just pulled to one side and explained why her actions are not appropriate.“But to be sacked, thats not the actions of a reputable employer and well-known brand like Birds.It comes just days after a -year-old woman was told she couldnt buy bread from Birds bakery because she didnt have a bank card.Former hosiery worker Edna Dalchin has never owned a bank card and prefers to pay with cash.She was stunned and embarrassed when staff told her to put items back because they could not take her money.Lesley Bird, chief operating officer at Birds Bakery, said: “At Birds, we take the safety of our staff and customers very seriously – and have very tight procedures in place during this pandemic.“A lot of our customer base are the elderly – many of them vulnerable – and it is our responsibility to keep them, and our staff, safe.“Like many other food outlets, during this pandemic we have asked customers to only use debit cards because notes and coins are not clean – and this poses a risk to our staff who are handling that money.“In the case of Megan Metcalfe she was taking cash from customers and then making payments with her own card.“This contravenes our current health and safety policy relating to Covid- and is also against company regulations.“It was with regret that we had to ask Megan to leave the business because of those two issues.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we And he called for support for aposshieldingapos people - due to be ended across England tomorrow - to be extended for regions under increased restrictions.Holding a press conference in the wake of his region being placed under stricter coronavirus restrictions, he called for the government to be clearer in communicating changes.He said: We would strongly recommend to the government that at the time a public or media statement is made affecting any area across the country, it must then follow that detailed information is immediately available at the same time as the making of that statement. If we donapost fix that hole in the system our test and trace arrangements will not be strong enough going into the winter, and they need to be, he added.  Mr Burnham also called on the government to extend support for aposshieldingapos people at increased risk from Covid- until the local restrictions are eased again. The shielding point I think is tremendously important. It cannot feel right for someone being at home today whoaposs been shielding for months, to hear that new restrictions are coming in in Greater Manchester and to fear what that might mean - and then to hear that aposoh, your support is about to be withdrawn and you have to go out to the shops to get your own.apos Clearly the government must be able to see that there is a mismatch in that messaging that will cause real anxiety in peopleaposs minds.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailHuge changes to millions of peopleaposs freedoms swept in last night with less than three hoursapos notice due to a surge in coronavirus cases. People in the whole of Greater Manchester may no longer meet anyone from outside their household indoors - including homes, pubs and gardens. The affected area also includes parts of West Yorkshire and Lancashire. However, people are allowed to continue to meet outdoors as long as they stay socially distanced. They can still go to work, travel, and go to the pub - though only with their own household. With the laws now dfering across England and the short notice, many people in Greater Manchester, Lancashire and West Yorkshire are confused about what they can and canapost do. Hereaposs the best explanation we can provide of what laws apply, where. Where the law will apply Greater Manchester:City of Manchester Trafford Stockport Oldham Bury Wigan Bolton Tameside Rochdale SalfordLancashire:Blackburn with Darwen Burnley Hyndburn Pendle RossendaleWest Yorkshire:Bradford Calderdale Kirklees What you can be fined for - and how much New laws will be passed to ban meeting people from other households in private homes or gardens. Police will be able to fine offenders £ for a first offence, doubling on each subsequent offence. Under previous similar laws the maximum fine was £,. Fines halvepaid within  days. There will be some exceptions, such as for household bubbles . Other rules - like not visiting care homes, not socialising with people in pubs, and not sharing cars - look set to be guidance rather than the law. However, there is already a nationwide legal ban on gatherings over  people outdoors and people must legally wear a face covering in shops and on public transport. We donapost yet know when the law will be published or take effect.What you canapost do You canapost meet up with friends or family indoors If you live in the above areas, you may no longer meet anyone from outside your household indoors. aposIndoorsapos includes private homes, businesses like pubs and restaurants, and private gardens . The exception is for people who are part of the same aposbubbleapos - more on this below. When it comes to private homes and gardens, this rule will be enforced by law with fines of £. In the rest of England, there is no longer a law on meeting people from other households indoors. However, guidance says meetings should comprise no than two households, and be socially distanced.   You canapost go to the pub with anyone outside your own household If you live in the above areas, you may still go to pubs, restaurants, bars and other venues that reopened from July . However, you may only go with members of your own household. You must not socialise with people you do not live with in other indoor public venues. You canapost go to a pub beer garden with anyone outside your own household Health Secretary Matt Hancock said the ban on socialising in indoor public venues will include pub beer gardens. This means you cannot go to the pub socially with anyone from outside your household - whether youaposre indoors or outdoors.  You canapost meet friends and family in their garden The ban on meeting other households in indoor spaces includes private gardens - even though theyaposre outdoors. This is because to get there, you often have to pass through the house. You canapost have visitors to your home from outside the new lockdown area You may not have visitors to your home from outside the new lockdown area. This will be illegal. But you can meet them in a pubic area like a parkyou follow social distancing rules.  You canapost visit relatives in care homes Last week the government announced care home visits in England could finally resume.  But in the new lockdown areas, care home visits will not resume. Guidance for them says: You should not visit friends or family in care homes, other than in exceptional circumstances. Care homes should restrict visits to these circumstances. You canapost travel in a car with people outside your household The guidance for the new lockdown area says: You should try not to share a vehicle with those outside your household or social bubble. If you need to, try to share the vehicle with the same people each time, keep to small groups and open windows for ventilation. You should also sit as far apart as possible within the vehicle, wear face coverings and clean the inside thoroughly and regularly. You shouldnapost travel to the lockdown area from Scotland The Scottish government issued new guidance today advising people living in Scotland not to travel to the new lockdown areas at all. The guidance says: Travel between Scotland and Greater Manchester, East Lancashire and parts of West Yorkshire should only be undertakenabsolutely essential. Anyone currently in the affected areas does not need toto Scotland early - but should be extra vigilant in monitoring for symptoms.What you can do You can meet up with friends or family outdoors People in the new lockdown area can continue to meet people outside their household in outdoor spaces - like a park, forest or the beach. This is still in line with guidance for the rest of England. The law only restricts gatherings of more than  people. However, guidance says you should only meet in groups of up to two households, or six people - whichever is larger. Each household should remain socially distant from each other.  You can meet people in your aposbubbleapos indoors Since June , people in England have been able to form a support bubble with one other household. To qualy, one of the two households has to have only one adult in it. For example, a single mum or a granddad living alone. If youaposre in a bubble, you can continue this even in the new lockdown areas like Greater Manchester. You should basically treat your two-household bubble asit is one household. You can stop shielding from tomorrow Most of the .million aposextremely clinically vulnerableapos people in England can stop shielding tomorrow. This means they can be asked toto work, and follow the same social distancing rules as the rest of the populationthey wish. This is unchanged in most of the new lockdown area. People in Greater Manchester, for example, can still stop shielding tomorrow. Exceptions are Luton and Blackburn with Darwen, where shielding should continue to August . In Leicester shielding also continues until at least August  and could run in some parts of the city beyond that.  You can go to work and use public transportneeded People living inside and outside of the new area can continue to travel in and out for work Workplaces must implement Covid- Secure guidance. Public transport will continue running for those who need it, with face coverings worn by all. You can have tradesmen in your home The guidance is not explicit on whether plumbers, builders or repair workers can work in your home in the new lockdown area. However, the government said they can continue to do so as before. You can travel in and out of the area You may continue to travel in and out of the new lockdown area, as long as you do not break the rules on meetings indoors. People from outside can take holidays in the new lockdown area,they follow the local rules. People who live inside the new area should continue to follow the ban on meeting other households indoors, eventheyaposre outside the zone at the time.  You can go to cafes, restaurants, the gym and other venues - but only with members of your own household All the venues that reopened on July  remain open, with a few exceptions in local areas where there is an outbreak. But you should only go with members of your own household – evenyou are going outside of the restricted area. You can go to a place of worship You can go to a place of worship, but you must socially distance from people outside of your household. The place of worship should also be following Covid-secure guidelines to keep people apart. Officials recommend at this time that,possible, prayer or religious services take place outdoors. This includes mosques, which are celebrating Eid.

Shortly after pm on Thursday, Health Secretary Matt Hancock announced that from midnight, people from dferent households in Greater Manchester, parts of Lancashire and parts of Yorkshire were no longer allowed to meet indoors. It means people in these areas will not be permitted to mix with other households - apart from those in their support bubbles - in private homes or gardens. Some exemptions will be put in place, including for the vulnerable, the government said. They will sign new regulations to make these changes legally enforceable. The regulations will give local authorities and police forces the powers to enforce these restrictions. Households may go to hospitality, for instance bars and pubs, but new guidance will make clear that two households should not go to hospitality together. Meanwhile local leaders and government have today agreed a number of changes to local restrictions in other areas. Below are the areas affected by the new restriction... Greater Manchester The rules apply to the whole of Greater Manchester after a number of hotspots were identied. Oldham, Trafford and Manchester were all in the  places with the highest Covid- infection rates. Figures released yesterday showed Oldham had overtaken Leicester, with . cases per , of the population. It was followed by Trafford, with . and Manchester with ..  Parts of East Lancashire It is no secret that Blackburn with Darwen has been cause for concern for some time, with the highest infection rate in England. Yesterday it had . cases per , of the population, and the council had issued fresh guidelines, including a limit on the number of visitors allowed into homes. The new measures go further, however, banning members of two households meeting indoors. Other affected areas are Burnley, Hyndburn, Pendle, Rossendale.  Parts of West Yorkshire Three West Yorkshire towns and cities feature in the  worst affected places in England - Bradford, Calderdale and Kirklees. Public Health England yesterday said there were . cases per , in the population in Bradford, making it the fourth worst affected area. It was followed by Calderdale in eighth place and Kirklees in tenth. They had rates of . and . per , respectively.  What is happening in Leicester  While social gathering restrictions remain in place in Leicester City, the area will benefit from the lting of restrictions that took place on  July in England, and all local restrictions currently in place in the neighbouring borough of Oadby and Wigston will end. It means from Monday  August restaurants, cafes, bars and hairdressers in Leicester City can get back to business but leisure centres, gyms and pools will remain closed.  In addition, cinemas and museums will open and religious ceremonies will be able to take place. And on Saturday  August, Luton will be brought in line with the rest of the country after signicant progress has been made in controlling the virus. Liz Kendall, MP for Leicester West, tweeted: Just been on call with Minister about LeicesterLockdown. The great news is our pubs, cafes, bars  restaurants can re-open and people can go on holiday with their own household.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPlans to restart wedding receptions have been scrapped and new face covering rules are coming in as the Government announced Englandaposs latest lockdown changes today. Boris Johnsonaposs update to the nations just as millions affected by new local lockdowns in northern England coronavirus hot-spots face were told to follow stricter new rules, and with little notice. Residents of Greater Manchester, and parts of East Lancashire and West Yorkshire were plunged into chaos overnight as new Covid- restrictions were brought in. The ban took effect from midnight with just three hoursapos warning, and prohibit people from meeting other households in all indoor settings, including private homes and gardens. At a press conference this afternoon, the Prime Minister outlined the reason for the new lockdowns, saying he had warned the Government would act aposswtly and decisivelyapos to stamp out local outbreaks - and more areas could follow. He also announced rule changes affecting all of England, declaring face coverings would be compulsory in more indoor settings including cinemas and churches. He postponed reopening of more settings including ice rinks, casinos and bowling alleys for another fortnight, along with wedding receptions of more than  people. He also put off reopening close-contact services - meaning beauty treatments like brows and facials due to restart tomorrow that many Brits will have booked in must be cancelled.  Englandaposs Chief Medical Officer Chris Whitty warned the UK had potentially aposreached the limitapos of how much society could reopen, as infections rise once again. Here are the key changes and rules you need to know about from tomorrow, August . All these venues are able to remain in most of England providing they can show they are aposCovid-secureapos:Hotels and BBs Holiday apartments or homes Cottages or bungalows Campsites Caravan parks Boarding houses Places of worship Libraries Community centres Restaurants, cafes and workplace canteens Bars Pubs Gyms Cinemas Nail bars Beauty salons Swimming pools, lidos and water parks Bingo halls Theatres and concert halls - but on the basis it’s not a live performance. They can only screen past performances for example Museums and galleries Hair salons and barbers Outdoor playgrounds Outdoor gyms Funfairs Theme parks Adventure parks and activities Amusement arcades Other indoor leisure centres and facilities - including indoor gaming, social clubs, model villages, and indoor attractions at aquariums and zoos. Face coverings and masks Face masks will be compulsory in more indoor spaces, in one of the biggest changes announced today affecting all of England. The coverings are already mandatory on public transport, unless you have a medical reason or disability that allows you to be exempt from the rules. That includes conditions like asthma, and also people accompanying someone with a condition who needs to be able to lip-read their companion. From August  the new rules will become law, and will required face coverings be worn in indoor settings where it is dficult to practise social distancing - including cinemas, galleries and houses of worship like churches. The PM will ask police to crack down harder on those breaking the rules. Read more about this rule change here.  You can visit cinemas, galleries and museums - but not have a big wedding reception Wedding receptions of more than  people have been banned throughout England with just  hours notice. Rules were set to change from August  in England to allow small, socially-distanced receptions of up to  people. However, the move was one of those postponed for at least two weeks today by Boris Johnson.  Wedding ceremonies of up to  people have already been allowed in England since July  and can continue - including in Greater Manchester, which is among the northern areas facing separate restrictions from today. However, guests must be socially-distanced and the ceremony must follow Covid-secure guidelines.  With face coverings mandatory in places of worship from August  - though itaposs not yet clearthereaposll be exemptions for the bride and groom. The PM also postponed the reopening of more indoor gatherings and businesses that were due to restart tomorrow. Casinos, bowling alleys, skating rinks and remaining close contact services must remain closed, he said Indoor performances will not resume - ruling out live music, theatre, and dance, and indoor classes. Larger crowds in sports venues and conference centres will also remain off limits Wedding receptions of up to  people will not be permitted, but ceremonies can continue to take place, in line with coronavirus guidelines. You can get a haircut - but you still canapost get your brows done Hairdressers and barbers remain open with protective measures - including face visors for those cutting hair. Nail and beauty salons are now open too. Beauty salons were given the go ahead to re-open on July , just over a week after hairdressers were given the green light. But there remains restrictions on procedures including eyebrow treatments, facials, eye lash tinting and face waxing. More treatments were due to be allowed from tomorrow, August . However the PM today announced the changes due to take effect on Saturday would be postponed at least another fortnight. What you still canapost do anywhere in England:  Large wedding receptions Attend sports matches in a large crowd Big gigs Nightclubs Casino Bowling alleys and skating rinks Indoor play areas including soft play Tattoo and piercing studios Massage parlours Indoor fitness and dance studios Conference centres, other than people who already work thereYou can visit friends and family indoors - but you still canapost hug People in most of England can have friends and family round to their house to eat, hang out and stay overnight - but they still can’t hug. You can also meet in all indoor settings like pubs and restaurants, provided they follow social distancing rules. Indoor gatherings will be allowed between two households who havenapost joined together in a “bubble”. Bubbles - a permanent joining of two households which let people break social distancing rules and stay over - still havenapost been expanded. Currently bubbles can be formed of two households. One of the bubble households has to have only one adult in it, such as a grandparent living alone, a single parent with kids, or a couple who live apart where at least one lives alone. Your household is allowed to meet with one other household at a time. That potentially includes staying over at someone’s house, as long as social distancing rules are followed indoors. More on the changes to these rules for northern lockdowns follow below.  Meeting outdoors Currently up to six people from up to six households can meet in a park or garden,they maintain social distancing - and that hasnapost changed for most of England except in the new lockdown areas. Two households of any size - for example, two families of four - can also meet outdoors, as long as they maintain social distancing. So you can either meet five friends from dferent households, or an unlimited number of friends from one household. This is guidance. The law only prohibits gatherings of more than  people - except for indoor gatherings in the new lockdown area . You can go to the pub - but you can only meet one other household inside Pubs, bars, restaurants, cafes and workplace canteens remain open. If youaposre indoors, you can only meet with people from one other household. And you should still maintain social distancing rules. That means staying either two metres apart, or one metre apart with mitigation measuresyou canapost manage two metres. It means no propping up the bar or standing in groups, and pubs will be encouraged to have table service where possible. All venues - from pubs to places of worship - will be expected to keep a record of people who visit, to enable contact tracing. More on the changes to these rules for northern lockdowns follow below.  You can go on staycation to English hotels, BBs and campsites - but not hostels Hotels, BBs, holiday apartments or homes, cottages or bungalows, campsites, caravan parks and boarding houses are all reopen to paying guests in England. They must follow coronavirus guidelines - but people will be able to stay overnight away from their home. Despite concerns over shared facilities, campsites are reopen too, as long as they have showers and washing-up blocks. Hostels with shared bedrooms cannot yet reopen. The government has not said people in northern regions cannot travel. People in the new lockdown zone, such as Greater Manchester, may continue to travel in and out of the new lockdown area, as long as you do not break the rules on meetings indoors.Large wedding receptions Attend sports matches in a large crowd Big gigs Nightclubs Casinos Bowling alleys and skating rinks Indoor play areas including soft play Tattoo and piercing studios Massage parlours Indoor fitness and dance studiosYou canapost send your child to school Only years R,  and  are allowed back to primary schools in England at the moment. The government wants all children back in September - but was forced to drop plans to do it earlier. Boris Johnson said today getting kids back to school by September remains a aposnational priority.apos  Shielding people can meet groups of friends outside Shielding was eased for .million vulnerable people in England earlier this morng. Shielding people can go out and meet up to five friends - andthey live alone, form a aposbubbleapos with another household. From August , the advice to shield ends completely. But Statutory Sick Pay and direct food parcels for the shielding will also end tomorrow. You canapost play cricket, football or rugby, except with your own household Recreation and sport will be allowed. But people should only play close-contact team sports - like football and rugby - with other members of their household. And indoor facilities including changing rooms and courts will remain closed. Cricket is also off limits for now - with Boris Johnson saying the ball is a natural vector of disease.  You can go back to the office or use public transport -your workplace is apossafeapos Guidelines on avoiding public transport unless itaposs absolutely necessary remain. The government has been urging workplaces to begin reopeningthey can follow social distancing guidelines indoors safely. Everyone  should carry on working from homeat all possible. You can travel abroad - with limits You can travel abroad - and aposair bridgesapos mean no quarantine for Brits heading back from summer holidays in some parts of Europe and farther afield. However the limits of the policy have been felt by Spain holidaymakers, after a series of outbreaks sparked the UK government to close the air bridge abruptly. The UK allows travellers coming from a select list of countries to arrive without a -day quarantine period, including Brits ing from holidays from those countries. See which countries remain on the air bridge list here.  Lockdown changes for Greater Manchester, east Lancashire, and West Yorkshire New laws are being passed to ban meeting people from other households in private homes or gardens, or travelling in cars together. People can still meet in a public area like a parkthey follow social distancing rules. People will also still be able to visit pubs or restaurants - but only with their own households, and they canapost meet up with others indoors - even in beer gardens. They also wonapost be able to visit care homes. There will be some exceptions, such as for household bubbles. The government shortly after midnight updated guidance saying the government would pass new laws to enforce changes to the new northern lockdowns. While it made clear people will be fined £ for breaking the rules in the localised restrictions, the law to enforce it did not exist at the time the lockdowns kicked in.

They are a lelineShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  JUL NewsopinionRicky Tomlinson joins protesters outside BBC Media City in Salford, Greater Manchester, at the broadcasters decision to axe free TV licences for . million pensioners " %, rgba, rgba, url"What is really going on in politics  Get our daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. In their  manesto the Conservatives pledged that free TV licences for the over s would be retained. But on Saturday this much-loved benefit comes to an end. The Tories are trying to pin the blame on the BBC but the responsibility lies entirely with them. They made a promise and now they are refusing to abide by their word. No wonder so many people feel betrayed. Free TV licences are not a perk. They are a leline for millions of pensioners for whom the telly is a source of companionship and a window into the outside world. The decision is especially cruel when so many older people are having to shield because of coronavirus. A government with a conscience would find the money to enable the BBC to maintain the benefit. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA bakery worker tried to get around her companyaposs no-cash rule by taking money from customers and paying at the till with her own card. And she was sacked when bosses found out - bringing to a sudden end a -year career with the same company.Megan Metcalfe told NottinghamshireLive that she was given her marching orders as her actions were deemed to amount to gross misconduct. Popular Birds Bakery has not been accepting cash for hygiene reasons since reopening following the coronavirus lockdown.They say it is to minimise any risk to staff and customers.  Yesterday, we reported how a -year-old customer was shocked and embarrassed when a Birds branch refused to sell her bread because she only had cash.And today Megan told of how many of the customers at the Birds store where she worked, in Radclfe-on-Trent, are elderly and donapost have a debit card. To make sure they didnapost leave empty-handed, the -year-old of Ruddington decided to ask them to put the money straight into her purse. She would then put the payment through on her card before showing them the receipt. The bakery business said it was with regret that they had to dismiss Megan because of her actions. I realise what I was doing was against company policy. But they had picked up the items and already gotten to the till ready to buy them, Megan said. Thereaposs no way I could let an elderly man or woman walk away telling them they could not buy it because they didnapost have a card. They had also already handled the stock so that would have to be binned or cleaned. Megan says she took around £ of payments in cash and put them through on her card and has kept receipts of the transactions.  She said she was suspended from work for a week with full pay on June  and appeared before a disciplinary hearing the week after before being dismissed from the company. I was just trying to do the right thing. I am really upset by it of course, she added. I worked at Birds for  years and  of them as a manager. I was told I was endangering staff membersapos lives by doing what I did. At no point did money transfer hands. It was straight into my purse and then I put the payment through on card and showed them the receipt. I should not have done it but I donapost like to let people down and a lot of these customers depend on us, coming to us every day. Lesley Bird, chief operating officer at Birds Bakery, said: “At Birds, we take the safety of our staff and customers very seriously – and have very tight procedures in place during this pandemic. A lot of our customer base are the elderly – many of them vulnerable – and it is our responsibility to keep them, and our staff, safe.

story: NewsCosta del Sol deserted as Brits stay away amid fears of coronavirus second waveEXCLUSIVE: Bars, beaches and restaurants have been left empty following the governments announcement to impose a -day quarantine for Brits ing from SpainShareCommentsByAdam Aspinall:,  JUL NewsThe Costa del Sol has been deserted as Brits stay away amid fears of a coronavirus second wave " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email The Costas are deserted as Brits stay away after Health Secretary Matt Hancock said a second wave of coronavirus is rolling across Europe.Usually busy hotels have been shutting their doors since the Government ordered quarantine for those ing from Spain. Businesses in popular resorts slammed the Government’s “draconian” move, which came just weeks after Spain was put on the UK’s list of safe countries. At Malaga airport, the gateway to the Costa del Sol for millions of Brits each year, half-empty planes landed throughout the day from airports across the UK. Many of the passengers who did make the trip said they were only doing so as they had a business or holiday home in the area. One tourist from Belfast said their flight was “barely % full” while another said theirs was “virtually empty”. Barely any Brits could be seen entering through arrivals, though there was a steady stream from nations such as France, Germany and Holland. A Spanish tour rep said: “This should be full of British right now . It’s so sad.” At the taxi rank, one of the many waiting drivers said: “Everybody is very angry with the British Government, it was a stupid decision by them, not based on facts.” Up the coast on the Costa Blanca, hotels in Benidorm began to close including the four-star Rio Park Hotel. Usually packed at this time of year, with % of its customers British package holiday tourists, it began to close its doors just six days after reopening. About four in five hotels in the town’s Rincon de Loix area are closed. Mr Hancock denied he was stoking up panic after he warned there was a “real danger” of the UK being hit by a fresh spike in cases. He said: “I think you can see a second wave starting to roll across Europe. We’ve got to do everything we can to prevent it from reaching these shores and to tackle it.” Jet said it will evacuate Brits on holiday in Spain and the Balearic and Canary Islands “up to and including August ”. Holidaymakers were told to cut short their holidays and book alternative flights. A spokeswoman said: “We apologise for any inconvenience caused.” Tonight it was announced that people ing from Luxembourg will have to quarantine for  days after a rise in cases there. It came amid speculation that other European countries including Belgium could be added to the list today. Spain’s tourism sector could take £billion hit this summer as the fresh restrictions take another chunk out of balance sheets already battered after months of lockdown. Bosses are hoping an upcoming review of the quarantine order could lt the restriction within days. Tourism Minister Reyes Maroto said: “They have given us a period of  days for the review.” She insisted resorts popular with Brits are “at low risk” of coronavirus and even “better” than the UK. Spain is still fighting for destinations such as the Canary and Balearic Islands to be excluded from the quarantine rule. Ms Maroto said: “There has been talk of a second wave of the pandemic but we’re not at all at that point. “The new outbreaks are under control and are in very specic places, and Spanish tourist destinations at the moment have very low levels of contagion. “That means people can enjoy their holidays there. The virus needs to be respected but that doesn’t mean we can’t have well-deserved holidays.” Spain announced , new cases on Wednesday, the highest -hour figure since May  when the entire country was still on full lockdown.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Summer is in full swing and the NHS Test and Trace team are working hard to stop the spread of the coronavirus.At Hussain is a locum optometrist who joined the NHS Test and Trace team. The -year-old, from Rochdale, is now dealing with people in Leicester who’ve tested positive for Covid-. A number of changes have been rolled out to the job in recent weeks - including a new measure to track down people who donapost answer calls from the team. Where contact tracers would have previously had four days to try and reach people, that’s been reduced in the outbreak groups.  Atexplains: “If after  hours we can’t make contact with them, we escalate it and a team will go to the household and conduct an interview instead of after  hours. That’s key,” he says. The new methods mean Ataposs vital job now involves so much more than just contact tracing. He went on: “When we call anyone from Leicester, we discuss with them in more detail support we can offer – such as help with food shopping and picking up prescription medication. ‘‘It’s hoped having people to do their essential shopping and pick up prescriptions will increase levels of compliance and make self-isolation easier.” Sarah Hartle , a dental hygienist from Manchester, is another NHS Test and Trace caseworker who has seen her job change to help fight coronavirus.  As pubs, restaurants and shops opened up, she and the team faced new challenges when tracing contacts, so they were given extra training to get the right information from people who’d tested positive for coronavirus. “What’s changed is the questions we’re asking the patients,” she says. “If they were in a shop, were they wearing a mask  Was the shopkeeper  Did they pay by cash or card  Were they maintaining social distancing  If you are doing all those things, the people in that particular shop are not classed as contacts. It’s all based on science. Social distancing does work.” And with the NHS Test and Trace team regularly updated on the latest advice and improvements in the system put in place, they’re able to give people the relevant help they need. She adds: “One recent patient needed a Hindi speaker. The system for that is now so simple and quick, the patient is only on hold for about  seconds and then youaposrere back with the interpreter.”

story: NewsopinionDr Miriam Stoppard: Ethnic minorities being failed by lack of inclusive planningThe pandemic has starkly revealed that BAME people are less likely to use Covid- testing services – we need to look at issues from their point of view to find solutionsShareCommentsByMiriam Stoppard:,  JUL NewsopinionTesting kit instructions can be hard to understand for people whose first language is not English " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe longer the pandemic lasts, the more inequality we uncover.Now we learn both access to testing and its uptake is uneven across all socioeconomic groups, with BAME coming out worst. It’s not just in the UK that ­disparities exist – it’s worldwide. Action is needed to correct this so people from ethnic minorities are included in national and local health planning. Catherine Dodds of Bristol ­University and Ibidun Fakoya from King’s College, London suggest the way forward in an editorial in the BMJ. To keep the R number below one, governments are relying on ­nationwide testing and contact tracing until we have a vaccination programme in place. But while we wait, inequalities mean BAME Covid- infections and deaths keep rising.As Dodds and Fakoya point out we already know uptake of medical testing and screening is uneven across cancer risk assessment, antenatal screening, and HIV testing. The NHS is aiming to expand testing with self-administered swab kits – but this strategy may serve minority groups badly, bearing in mind a  UK study found uptake of HIV self-sampling kits among them was low compared with other groups. Most admitted they would probably not use the kits. Behind this reluctance were privacy issues and kits with complicated instructions that were inappropriately worded for people whose first language wasn’t English. Dodds and Fakoya emphasise until these faults are corrected it’s dficult to see how trust can be built up among our ethnic communities. Isn’t it time we looked at these ­disparities from the BAME point of view, and started framing instructions in a form that’s understandable, acceptable and useful for ethnic minorities instead of imposing a “one-size-fits-all” approach  Given the disproportionate and devastating impact this pandemic has already had among our ethnic minority communities, testing equality needs to be addressed in Covid- screening.

No-one believes me when I say the vets removed more than a kilo of skin, they think Iaposm joking, but itaposs absolutely true and Neoaposs all the better for it. Ida Gilbert, an advance practitioner in veterinary ophthalmology , said Neo was considered an urgent case due to his struggles with poor vision, which irritated his eyes, and extremely heavy facial folds. The irritation caused him to rub his eyes repeatedly making them sore, and he became anxious around anyone touching his face, which made using eye drops impossible. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA grieving mum-of-two who had lost her dad was hounded with unwanted gts and messages by a company boss she met on dating website Plenty of Fish. Emma Murby, , had split up with Timothy Green but he bombarded her with flowers, chocolates and sent her a new vacuum cleaner in a bid to win her back while she was in mourning. The teacher, who lives in the village of Eldwick, near Bingley, West Yorkshire, begged the -year-old company managing director to leave her alone - but he left her scores of messages, a Pandora ring and even posed as one of her friends to send her a condolence card. Police eventually the former golf club boss for harassment. At Stockport magistrates court, Green from Wilmslow, Cheshire who runs a company which provides safety inspections admitted harassment. He was banned from contacting Miss Murby for two years under the terms of a restraining order. The court heard the couple had met online in April  on POF and met in person for the first time at the end of that month. Prosecutor Mark Pritchard said: They then had a long-distance relationship where the defendant was living in Wilmslow and the complainant was living in Eldwick. They spent time together at weekends and sometimes met up in the week. At this point the complainant says it was a normal relationship and that she was happy. In August last year she moved in with him for a short period of time and their relationship became strained.  She moved back and after some time the relationship ended. That is when the defendant began his unrelenting course of harassment towards his victim. On March  this year the victim told police she had broken up with the defendant but he continued to contact her. He continued to send flowers and leave voicemails asking her to call him. She replied saying aposI am blocking your calls and voicemails donapost call me again. Stop harassing me.Leave me alone we are not together any more. Do not contact me anywhere.apos But he left her  messages in March,  in April, seven in May. After the victimaposs father died he sent messages to her reporting to be her friend Nick and sent her a condolence card. On the day of her fatheraposs funeral he messaged her saying he had been in a dark place had continued to send messages and cards after from a number of dferent accounts on Plenty of Fish- which all used the same photograph of him.  On May  he sent a vacuum cleaner part to her address which she believes he did to have a reason to contact her. Between  June and  June this year he contacted a friend of the victim numerous times asking about her. On June  he sent her a Pandora ring which she had owned when they were together with tape attached to it. Green later told police he thought Miss Murby had PTSD and that she was blaming him for it. He said he blamed her for him being on anti-depressants. In mitigation his lawyer Steven McHugh said: He is mortied at the position he is in today. He fears going to prison and is taking things seriously. He is not looking for favours and is realistic. The last point of contact was on  June and he wishes to move on with his le. He does not object to the restraining order. He does not wish to reacquaint himself with the complainant. He did not threaten her when he contacted her and had a mistaken belief that contacting her would resurrect the relationship. He pleaded guilty at he earliest opportunity and accepts there was no provocation at all.

Talking of the cleaning plans, one person said: Iaposm far too lazy to be this organised but well done you!! Another asked: Do you have a template at all  I struggle a lot with lack of motivation and canapost get anything done. This would help so much to tick off each day week or month. A third commented: I think this is brilliant! Well done you for being so organised! I’m going to try and take a leaf out of your book! You sound like superwoman to me added a fourth.  However one added: Le is too short. Someone once said to me, live le, no one wants to be remembered for cleaning their house. And another said: Blimey do you do anything but clean  As some people still couldnapost believe how much she cleans every day, she was forced to explain just how long it takes on average to complete each task. Daily tasks include:Make beds -  minutes, my son makes his own bed and i just straighten it upTidy up all rooms -  minutes, putting hair make up stuff away and the odd toy Pick up washing -  minute - the boys in this house have a decent aim. Wipe down bathrooms - a minute per bathroom - so maybe  minutes in total giving  minutes to get between the  Put in a load - again no more than  minutes Hoover downstairs -  minutes Empty dishwasher -  minutes Hoover upstairs -  minutes Wipe down work tops -  minutes Wipe down cabinets -  minutes Load dishwasher -  minutes Clean toilets -  minutes So all in all -  minutes  Plus give it five minutes rising and drying the dog food, maybe another five minutes generally cleaning the dining table, extra sweep of the floor after tea etc, wiping down the hob. On a weekend, its probably more like an hour a day with the extras on the Sat Sunday cleaning. Although most members were supportive of Nikoleaposs rigid cleaning schedule, she did receive some criticism which she later addressed. Responding she wrote: Can I just say that I love my children and husband very much. I work  hours a week and manage no problem to spend quality time with them. This cleaning I already do but I like a good visual, which also helps with delegation.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe German police search of the garden allotment where the Madeleine McCann prime suspect lived was “an act of pure desperation,” according to his lawyer. Officers spent two days digging up the foundations of the Christian Brueckneraposs former rented shack - removing concrete rubble from the remains. Diggers, snfer dogs, ground penetrating radar and drones were used to examine the site near Hanover where he stayed after Madeleine vanished. When they left on Wednesday evening, they refused to saythey had discovered anything on the site. But it is believed they lted a stone slab to find an underground cellar full of corrugated iron which a snfer dog reacted to and started barking. The allotment, used as a country escape for city dwellers, was reduced to a patch of sand after the search team left.  There is one old sign left nailed onto one tree trunk at the site entrance warning parents they are aposliable for their childrenaposthey trespass. Brueckner, aged , was said to have stockpiled insulation in the shabby grey shack, which had been demolished before the search took place. The next door neighbour said the allotment lease holder had allowed him to stay there in  after meeting him at a festival and hearing he was homeless. But he was kicked off after falling out with neighbours about a year later.But his lawyer Friedrich Fuelscher calls the search of the site a pure desperate act of the public prosecutoraposs office. This week locals urged police to search a second site an hour away in Braunschweig but his lawyer said “They wonapost find anything there either”. And he ridiculed the public prosecutoraposs office by saying: “Apparently, itaposs hard for investigators to admit they backed the wrong horse. At the start of the search the convicted rapist, who is serving a jail sentence for drug offences, said he was withdrawing his request for an early release.  His full sentence is due to finish in Janaury next year but he is still facing sentence for the rape of a  year old woman in Potugal. But as soon as officers left his allotment site his lawyer revealed he was again applying for early release. The news puts further pressure on police to find evidence which could keep him behind bars. It is believed they have evidence he was in Praia da Luz in Portugal on the night Madeleine went missing in  and that he received a  minute phone call from the area.

title: puppy saved meat new legs
story: NewsTwo-legged puppy saved from death in dog meat slaughterhouse finds loving homePoor pup Emma Roo was just eight weeks old when she was mutilated in a slaughterhouse as they prepared to sell her for meat. But now the playful Dalmatian is happy and safe in a loving new homeShareCommentsByThomas McArthur:,  JUL NewsEmma smiles for the camera alongside mum, Misha " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - Weekly #TeamDogSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA two-legged Dalmatian has found a loving home after being rescued from a dog meat slaughterhouse where she had both her front paws cruelly cut off. The brave pooch Emma Roo was rescued in  from a butchers in Xi’an, China, but not before she had her front legs, part of her tail and the tips of her ears cut away.  She was only about eight weeks old at the time, rescuers believe, and may have been given to meat traders because of a small toe defect. Most of the animals killed for the meat trade in China are stolen or abandoned pets or guard dogs, as well as stray street dogs snatched from towns and cities. Slaughterhouses in the dog meat industry remove an animal’s limbs without any pain relief as they believe it produces adrenaline, which tenderises the remaining meat. After being rescued and taken to a veterinary practice in Bejing, Emma was rehomed for two years, before winding up back at the same clinic in .  The Chinese clinic then turned to Dalmatian Rescue, a US non-profit organisation, in their quest to get Emma a loving forever home. Lelong Dog lover Misha Rackclf Hunt, ,  from Charleston, South Carolina spotted Emma online and fell in love immediately.  I remember first seeing Emma online - she has the most human-like amber coloured eyes. I didnapost even think about the logistics of it. I knew this dog was set to me for a reason. When I met her, I thought she might be cold or not interested in people from the trauma but she came up straight into my arms. By the time we finished our five-hour road trip home, itaposs like she knew I was her person and that I was never going to leave her.  Misha took the dog in - who is now as playful and loving as any other pet. She said: “Eventually, Emma arrived in the US on January ,  – just weeks before the export of animals was banned due to Covid-. “When I first brought her home, she would scream at the top of her lungs whenever I left the room. She was always protective over her food and toys. At one point, she would even guard random pieces of my clothing because she was scared that it would be taken away.”Now safe in the US, Emma has attracted , Instagram fans, with Misha and Dalmatian Rescue raising funds through social media to get Emma a custom front wheel cart from Eddieaposs Wheels and to raise awareness about the cruel trade in dog meat worldwide.

title: analysis dundee have right to feel aggrieved
story: The   Championship season will kick off with a bang as Dundee head to fellow-promotion contenders Hearts for a mouth-watering opening day clash at Tynecastle.James McPake’s Dark Blues are expected to go head-to-head with Robbie Neilson’s Jambos in the race to the Premiership this coming season and will have the chance to lay down a marker straight away.Kicking off on the weekend of October , this season’s second tier will be a shorter affair than usual with only  matches and teams facing each other just three times.That means it’s the luck of the draw for home advantage in key games.And it’s fair to say Dundee’s luck hasn’t been in.As well as playing relegated Hearts away twice, the Dark Blues face two trips to last season’s runners-up Inverness and visit fourth-placed Ayr United twice, teams expected to be in the mix once again.On top of that there are two away games on the plastic parks of both Alloa and Queen of the South – the first of those on Boxing Day before the Dee end their campaign at Palmerston on April .With an odd number of games, half the teams would also miss out on one home game and, once more, lady luck hasn’t shined on the Dark Blues with  home matches and  away.With money tight at the club due to the coronavirus shutdown, Dundee have the right to feel aggrieved they will have to go with one less home game than others as well as only having one big pay day from a sizeable Hearts travelling support.That is, providing fans will be allowed inside the stadiums by that point.On paper, James McPake and his men have been handed a dficult Championship calendar but it’s also one with opportunity.The opening day Hearts clash will kick off the campaign with one of the biggest games of the season. However, it’s also a chance to lay down a marker.Grab a positive result there and the Dark Blues head into two home games on the bounce with Morton and newly-promoted Raith Rovers coming to town before the end of October – an opportunity to get off to a flying start.On the back of a trip to face Ayr, Dundee play Dick Campbell’s Arbroath at Dens before a Highlands clash with Inverness and then facing a Dunfermline side that has strengthened well over the past few weeks.After a Boxing Day trip to Dumfries, it’s the only midweek fixture of the campaign – home to Alloa – four days before hosting Hearts in what’s likely to be one of the biggest matches of the calendar for the Dens men.With only  of the  matches before the turn of the year, getting  off to a strong start will be essential to any promotion bid.That’s where the fixture list looks to be in Dundee’s favour – successive home games against the Jambos, Ayr and Inverness with trips to Raith and Arbroath in between.That run from the start of the year through to March’sto Tynecastle will be the key to success for James McPake and his men before heading into the final eight matches.The Dark Blues won’t be too happy with the card they’ve been dealt by the SPFL but defiance in the face of adversity is a trait at Dens Park.And come the final day on a Friday night at Queen of the South, the players will still fancy they can finish up on top and get the club back to the big time – eventhey have to do it the hard way.A full fixture list can be found here.For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.Newsletter Get top stories straight to your inbox every day.SUBSCRIBE HERE!Latest blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - title: calls for action after vandals strike again at city cemetery
story: Sickened relatives have called for action after vandals struck again at Dundee#s Birkhill Cemetery.A grave was discovered splattered in white paint, and a statue was also stolen from another plot this week.These latest incidents of #wanton# vandalism have brought three local woman together to urge Dundee City Council to install CCTV cameras and lighting at the cemetery.Jane Hunt, from Kirkton said she was shocked and upset to discover that her dad Robert#s grave had been targeted.She said: #My niece Morgan Grubb, also from Kirkton, visited her grandfather, my dad#s grave on Wednesday night.#When she arrived she was horried to discover that it was covered in white paint.#She immediately contacted me and I was disgusted and angry to see the damage for myself.#I have reported this to the council and the police.#This must stop happening. This is far from the first act of wanton vandalism at the cemetery and something must be done by the council to stop those responsible.#The damage on Wednesday was reportedly caused by three youths seen at the cemetery.Karen Longmuir, whose son Dale Flanagan is also buried at Birkhill said: #I was told that there were three lads in the cemetery on Wednesday potentially stealing things and causing damage#I came straight here but thankfully on this occasion my son#s grave was not touched , although other people have suffered damage.#Karen said her son#s grave has been the target of vandals three times, and on each occasion a small motor bike was stolen from his grave.She said: #My son was killed in a motorbike accident. I am upset and angry that this damage is continuing.#Dundee City Council have been asked time and time again to install CCTV cameras to stop this happening and to also erect lights to light up the area at night time.#Lesley Nicoll, whose son Lee Welsh is buried in the same part of the cemetery said that she too was frustrated and angry at damage caused to graves.Lesley said: #Lee#s grave has also been targeted by these mindless vandals in the past. Luckily for us too on this occasion nothing was taken from or damaged.#She added: #We are appealing to the council to take action to stop these acts of vandalism happening again.#When the Tele approached Dundee City Council for comment, Councillor Anne Rendall responded that vandalism was #completely unacceptable#.The Neighbourhood Services Convener added:  “This sort of behaviour causes a great deal of distress to families and friends who have lost someone dear to them.“There is no place for this behaviour and we have reported this matter to the police.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.Newsletter Get top stories straight to your inbox every day.SUBSCRIBE HERE!Latest blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Eveningwebsite and Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening  n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb + ePaper n t t t n t t t n t t t tDuration: n t t t t Month n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayEnjoy the digital edition of the Eveningnewspaper on your smartphone, tablet and computer.Unlimited access to all articles on the Eveningwebsite. title: deputy scottish conservative leader liam kerr rules himself out of leadership race
story: North-east MSP Liam Kerr has pledged his support to Douglas Ross#s campaign to be the next leader of the Scottish Conservatives.The -year-old became deputy leader of the Scottish Conservatives last year, alongside Annie Wells, and there were suggestions he could feel ready to take the next step, following Jackson Carlaw#s departure.However, he has given his support to Moray MP Douglas Ross, stating he would be #delighted to back a fellow Conservative from the region#.Mr Kerr said: #In these dficult times it is important the party unites behind both proven and strong candidates as soon as possible to ensure we can expose this dreadful SNP government.#The best way to do that is to back Douglas Ross and that#s what I#ll be doing.#We must never forget the north-east is a powerhouse and I#m delighted to back a fellow Conservative from the region.#An employment lawyer before his election as a north-east regional list MSP in , Mr Kerr has held the key justice brief for the Holyrood party since .Mr Carlaw quit the role after less than six months in the job, amid mounting concerns over the state of the party and its ability to defend the union at the upcoming election.Moray MP Douglas Ross emerged as the firm favourite almost immediately after the announcement and formally confirmed on Friday that he is vying for the role.For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.Newsletter Get top stories straight to your inbox every day.SUBSCRIBE HERE!Latest blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - title: dundee united aberdeen jim mclean new firm dave bowman
story: It’s one of the first fixtures in the Premiership calendar that Dundee United fans would have picked out.And Tangerines hero Dave Bowman believes the club’s ‘New Firm’ rivalry with Aberdeen ran deeper than most for iconic gaffer Jim McLean.The first top-flight clash between the sides since March  is pencilled in for October .The game will come nearly four decades on from an era in which they enjoyed success on the continent and regularly competed for domestic trophies with Old Firm duo Celtic and Rangers, often beating the Glasgow giants.With  miles separating United and the Dons, and because it isn’t a traditional rivalry, some didn’t take the fixture as seriously as the Dundee derby.However, Bowman insists McLean was hell-bent on emulating and exceeding Sir Alex Ferguson’s achievements, particularly in Europe.Sir Alex won several trophies during his time in the Granite City, including the Cup Winners’ Cup and Uefa Super Cup in .McLean’s Tangerines came close, losing the  European Cup semi-final to Roma and the Uefa Cup Final to IFK Gothenburg three years later.Bowman – player transition coach at Dundee United – believes the legendary boss became fixated with winning in Europe and lting an ultimately-elusive Scottish Cup.“He probably was and, for everything he did, it’s unbelievable he never won the Scottish Cup or went on to win something in Europe,” the -year-old said.“We got there that often in the Scottish and never won it. I was lucky enough to play under Ivanin  but I’d lost three before we’d managed to get one.“Jim was manager for a few before then as well so that was probably big thing for him, not being able to do the clean sweep of Scottish football.“Aberdeen were the benchmark, with the New Firm at the time, the two of us were competing against one another.“Them having won European titles probably was sore for him, especially having gone so close.“You look at Roma and then Gothenburg it was, obviously, a big thing for him.”Bowman, who would go on to make  appearances for the club, checked in at Tannadice in  and was part of United’s efforts to make the Uefa Cup showpiece that season.They, arguably, could go down in history as the club’s greatest-ever side.However, the former Hearts man was quick to hail McLean’s title-winning side of  as the best of all.“I would still say when they won the league in  was their best team, what an achievement that was for the club,” he added.“But he kept on evolving the team by bringing myself, Jim McInally and Iain Ferguson to the club in .“When I look back at my time, the players I played with were absolutely brilliant.“They were top professionals as well with the way they conducted themselves off the park. That’s probably why they got so much success.“The likes of Heggie , Davey , Eamonn , Luggy , Holtyand Maurice , they were all great.“For Jimmy Mac, Fergie and I to come into that, playing with them week-in, week-out, it certainly makes your football a lot easier to do.”Bowman looks back on their European adventures with great fondness, hailing the Arabs as some of the best supporters on the continent.“When you look back at the  Uefa Cup run and we were playing Lens in the first round, there wasn’t loads of press and fans but the hype grew as we went on,” he continued.“As we went through the rounds you could see it building.“The fans were brilliant. They’d travel everywhere – the crowds for Barcelona, Monchengladbach and Gothenburg in the final were exceptional.“People even came to Romania to see us play Craiova, it was an Iron Curtain country at the time so that was dficult for their visas and getting there.“It just shows you exactly what United fans were and are still about.”LEE WILKIE: Coronavirus effect for Dundee United may be survival this season, then kick on in the next campaign" title"#LEE WILKIE: Coronavirus effect for Dundee United may be survival this season, then kick on in the next campaign# # Evening " src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp lee-wilkie-dundee-united-fc-micky-mellon embed # secretKqynNAaff" data-secret"KqynNAaff" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.Newsletter Get top stories straight to your inbox every day.SUBSCRIBE HERE!Latest blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Eveningwebsite and Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening  n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb + ePaper n t t t n t t t n t t t tDuration: n t t t t Month n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayEnjoy the digital edition of the Eveningnewspaper on your smartphone, tablet and computer.Unlimited access to all articles on the Eveningwebsite.
